citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
An alpaca was observed by an APHIS official to have moderate overgrowth of one mandibular (bottom) incisor, which is
starting to curl upwards and contact the upper lip, and mild overgrowth of an additional mandibular incisor. The facility
indicated that they did not notice this issue prior to the inspection. Overgrowth of teeth can cause pain and interfere with
an animal's ability to eat, potentially creating an impact on the welfare of the animal.
The facility must ensure that this animal health problem is communicated to the attending veterinarian and addressed
appropriately. Additionally, the facility must ensure that adequate daily observations of all animals are conducted to
assess their health and well-being, and that any problems of animal health, behavior, and well-being are conveyed to the
attending veterinarian in a timely manner. To be corrected by September 18, 2025.

On July 2, 2025, it was discovered that many chickens were missing from the flock. The licensee acknowledged that the
chickens were not locked up in their coop the night before, as the staff forgot to complete this task prior to leaving the
facility. Therefore, these chickens were only protected from predators by a fence. According to the licensee, the chickens
were predated.
The failure of the facility to properly place these chickens within a safe enclosure for the night resulted in their deaths. The
facility must ensure that handling of all animals is done as carefully as possible in a manner that does not cause trauma,
physical harm, or unnecessary discomfort. To be corrected by September 15, 2025.

The water receptacle in an enclosure housing three cattle and one bison contained a large accumulation of flocculent
brown material adhered to the sides, as well as debris floating on the surface.
Dirty water may harbor disease and pests and may cause the animals to decrease their intake of water. Per this Section,
potable water must be provided as often as necessary for the health and comfort of the animals, and all water receptacles
shall be kept clean and sanitary.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
